SqlBulkCopyColumnMapping.summary: Defines the mapping between a column in a instance's data source and a column in the instance's destination table.

remarks.para: Column mappings define the mapping between data source and the target table.

If mappings are not defined - that is, the collection is empty - the columns are mapped implicitly based on ordinal position. For this to work, source and target schemas must match. If they do not, an will be thrown.
If the collection is not empty, not every column present in the data source has to be specified. Those not mapped by the collection are ignored.
You can refer to source and target columns by either name or ordinal. You can also mix by-name and by-ordinal column references in the same mappings collection.

example.para: The following example bulk copies data from a source table in the AdventureWorks sample database to a destination table in the same database. Although the number of columns in the destination matches the number of columns in the source, and each destination column is in the same ordinal position as its corresponding source column, the column names do not match. objects are used to create a column map for the bulk copy.
example.note: This sample will not run unless you have created the work tables as described in Bulk Copy Example Setup.
example.para: This code is provided to demonstrate the syntax for usingSqlBulkCopyonly. If the source and destination tables are in the same SQL Server instance, it is easier and faster to use a Transact-SQL INSERT … SELECT statement to copy the data.

ctor.name: default
ctor.summary: Parameterless constructor that initializes a new object.
ctor.remarks: If you use this constructor, you must then define the source for the mapping using the property or the property, and define the destination for the mapping using the property or the property.

example.para: The following example bulk copies data from a source table in the AdventureWorks sample database to a destination table in the same database. Although the number of columns in the destination matches the number of columns in the source, the column names and ordinal positions do not match. objects are used to create a column map for the bulk copy.
example.note: This sample will not run unless you have created the work tables as described in Bulk Copy Example Setup.
example.para: This code is provided to demonstrate the syntax for using SqlBulkCopy only. If the source and destination tables are in the same SQL Server instance, it is easier and faster to use a Transact-SQL INSERT … SELECT statement to copy the data.

ctor.name: sourceColumnOrdinalIntegerAndDestinationOrdinalInteger
ctor.param: The ordinal position of the source column within the data source.
The ordinal position of the destination column within the destination table.
ctor.summary: Creates a new column mapping, using column ordinals to refer to source and destination columns.

example.para: The following example bulk copies data from a source table in the AdventureWorks sample database to a destination table in the same database. Although the number of columns in the destination matches the number of columns in the source, the column names and ordinal positions do not match. objects are used to create a column map for the bulk copy based on the ordinal positions of the columns.
example.note: This sample will not run unless you have created the work tables as described in Bulk Copy Example Setup.
example.para: This code is provided to demonstrate the syntax for using SqlBulkCopy only. If the source and destination tables are in the same SQL Server instance, it is easier and faster to use a Transact-SQL INSERT … SELECT statement to copy the data.

ctor.name: sourceColumnOrdinalIntegerAndDestinationColumnString
ctor.param: The ordinal position of the source column within the data source.
The name of the destination column within the destination table.
ctor.summary: Creates a new column mapping, using a column ordinal to refer to the source column and a column name for the target column.

example.para: The following example bulk copies data from a source table in the AdventureWorks sample database to a destination table in the same database. Although the number of columns in the destination matches the number of columns in the source, the column names and ordinal positions do not match. objects are used to create a column map for the bulk copy.

example.para: This code is provided to demonstrate the syntax for using SqlBulkCopy only. If the source and destination tables are in the same SQL Server instance, it is easier and faster to use a Transact-SQL INSERT … SELECT statement to copy the data.

ctor.name: sourceColumnStringAndDestinationOrdinalInteger
ctor.param: The name of the source column within the data source.
The ordinal position of the destination column within the destination table.
ctor.summary: Creates a new column mapping, using a column name to refer to the source column and a column ordinal for the target column.

example.para: The following example bulk copies data from a source table in the AdventureWorks sample database to a destination table in the same database. ctor.name: sourceColumnStringAndDestinationColumnString
ctor.param: The name of the source column within the data source.
The name of the destination column within the destination table.
ctor.summary: Creates a new column mapping, using column names to refer to source and destination columns.

example.para: The following example bulk copies data from a source table in the AdventureWorks sample database to a destination table in the same database. Although the number of columns in the destination matches the number of columns in the source, the column names and ordinal positions do not match. objects are used to create a column map for the bulk copy.

DestinationColumn.summary: Name of the column being mapped in the destination database table.
DestinationColumn.value: The string value of the property.
DestinationColumn.remarks: The and properties are mutually exclusive. The last value set takes precedence.

example.para: The following example bulk copies data from a source table in the AdventureWorks sample database to a destination table in the same database. Although the number of columns in the destination matches the number of columns in the source, the column names and ordinal positions do not match. objects are used to create a column map for the bulk copy.
example.note: This sample will not run unless you have created the work tables as described in Bulk Copy Example Setup.
example.para: This code is provided to demonstrate the syntax for using SqlBulkCopy only. If the source and destination tables are in the same SQL Server instance, it is easier and faster to use a Transact-SQL INSERT … SELECT statement to copy the data.

DestinationOrdinal.summary: Ordinal value of the destination column within the destination table.
DestinationOrdinal.value: The integer value of the property, or -1 if the property has not been set.
DestinationOrdinal.remarks: The and properties are mutually exclusive. The last value set takes precedence.
